awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Towards an Accurate, High-Fidelity Modeling System for Multiphysics and Multiscale Coastal Ocean Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
In correspondence with global warming and fast expansion of human activities in coastal waters, it is now becoming urgently needed to advance our modeling capabilities to a level of direct, high-fidelity simulation of many emerging, real-world, multiphysics, multiscale coastal ocean flow problems. Examples of these problems include oil spill at bottom of oceans, tidal energy extraction in coastal waters, etc. Currently, essentially there is no model at this level of simulation. The objective of this project is to develop computational methods and an unprecedented computer modeling system, which will be not only applicable to such problems but also a new platform to study many other problems.

In particular, a geophysical fluid dynamics model and a fully 3D fluid dynamics model are integrated via domain decomposition and two-way coupling into a single modeling system, in which the former captures mesoscale [O(10) km - O(10,000) km], background ocean currents and the latter resolves sub-mesoscale [O(1) m - O(10) km], complicated, local phenomena. The objective will be realized via three tasks: 1) Methods and algorithms with regard to solution accuracy, computational efficiency, and transmission condition. 2) Numerical experiments on the methods and algorithms, their validation in test problems, and a showcase application. 3) Development of a robust, efficient software package of the modeling system. The educational component aims at increasing awareness of students, especially those from underrepresented groups, on new computational problems and necessity for new methods of their solution, stimulating their interest in numerical algorithms and model development. The activities of this component include a series of seminars, teaching material development, etc.

por.por_cntn:
Modeling various ocean flow phenomena in emerging problems (e.g., oil spills and offshore wind energy) has become increasingly essential. In general, such flows are multiscale, multiphysics in nature, and conventionally they are simulated or better simulated by multiple sets of differential equations. This project aims to study the coupling of different sets of differential equations and simulate the ocean flows, producing the following results. 

    1) Analysis is made on the convergence of computation of coupled advection-diffusion equations via the conventional Schwarz and waveform Schwarz relaxation methods. Optimized interface algorithms are presented to speed up the convergence of Schwarz iteration in computing the discretized coupled equations (e.g., convergence within two times of iteration). The performance of these algorithms may remain largely true for nonlinear equations. Comparing the conventional and waveform relaxation approaches shows that the former is relatively inexpensive regarding computational loads. 

    2) Numerical methods/algorithms, together with a software package, have been developed for coupling between the geophysical fluid dynamics (GFD) equations and the Navier-Stokes (NS) equations. The methods/algorithms and the software have been tested and validated via numerical experiments. The GFD-NS system is the first of its kind and can simulate many emerging multiscale, multiphysics ocean flows beyond the reach of the existing models in the community. The figure shows a sample simulation of such flows, which captures the processes from the propagation of tsunami waves in background ocean all the way to their evolution on a beach and then their impact at a beachfront house.   

    3) Investigations have been made for GFD-NS interface conditions and algorithms, showing that different interface conditions and algorithms do lead to differences in computed results. For the development of a uniformly 2nd-order accurate GFD-NS modeling system, a method called BFECC developed for the hyperbolic equations was extended to interpolation for interface treatment, which enhances a 1st-order interpolation (global accuracy, e.g., linear interpolation) to 2nd-order interpolation with a slight increase of computational load. Besides, a super-convergence phenomenon (4th order accuracy) of the BFECC is discovered.  

    4) We proposed to couple the numerical solutions of PDEs via machine learning (ML). The study deals with the computation of coupled Poisson equations and coupled advection-diffusion equations. Artificial neuron networks (ANNs) provide solutions at the interfaces. The ANNs are trained by local solutions for the equations. Additionally, preliminary work is conducted on machine learning interface solutions of Navier-Stokes equations.

The analysis and development of numerical methods promote the coupling of numerical solutions for differential equations. For instance, the BFECC method is applicable at interfaces of different sets of differential equations. The ML coupling of PDE solutions may lead to a new paradigm for computed coupled PDEs. As an essential product of this project, the GFD-NS system sets up an unparalleled platform to directly simulate multiscale, multiphysics ocean flows in various disciplines, such as environmental science (e.g., oil spills from the seabed), coastal resilience (e.g., waves impact on seawall), and renewable energy (e.g., ocean flow stemming from ocean foundation of offshore wind energy). The system has started attracting attention in the communities of these disciplines. A few students are trained by this project and have been exposed to research at other schools.
